verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Ezekiel consistently emphasizes the prophetic nature of his message, indicating divine authority as the source.

verses.text: "Son of man, set your face against the sons of Ammon and prophesy against them.
verses.comment: The phrase 'son of man' highlights Ezekiel's role as a representative of humanity and anticipates Jesus's use of this title in the Gospels (Matt. 8:20).

verses.text: Say to the sons of Ammon, 'Hear the word of the Lord GOD! Thus says the Lord GOD: Because you said, "Aha!" over My sanctuary when it was profaned, and over the land of Israel when it was made desolate, and over the house of Judah when they went into exile,
verses.comment: The Ammonites' rejoicing at the downfall of Israel points to the seriousness of the profanation of sacred things. This foreshadows Jesus's teaching respecting the temple's sanctity (John 2:19).

verses.text: therefore, I will hand you over to the people of the east for a possession. They shall set up their encampments among you and make their homes among you; they shall eat your fruit and drink your milk.
verses.comment: The 'people of the east' refers to invading tribes. The forfeiture of the land echoes later Gospel teaching on stewardship and responsibility (Luke 19:26).

verses.text: And I will make Rabbah a pasture for camels and the cities of Ammon a resting place for flocks. Then you will know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Desolation transforming cities into pastures recalls divine judgment on pride and lack of reverence for the holy. Knowing the Lord is a repeated theme—pointing toward ultimate revelation through Christ.

verses.text: For this is what the Lord GOD says: Because you have clapped your hands and stamped your feet and rejoiced with all your hatred against the land of Israel,
verses.comment: Gestures of contempt and joy at others' downfall are condemned, reflecting a moral order later elevated in New Testament commands to love one's enemies (Matt. 5:44).

verses.text: therefore I will stretch out My hand against you and deliver you as spoil to the nations. I will cut you off from the peoples and make you perish from the lands. I will destroy you, and you shall know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Divine judgment followed by the repeated purpose, 'so you shall know that I am the LORD,' emphasizes the overarching goal: recognition of God's unique authority, later fulfilled in Christ's redemptive revelation.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord GOD: Because Moab and Seir said, 'Look, Judah is like all the other nations,'
verses.comment: Moab and Edom (Seir) denied the chosen status of Judah, foreshadowing the fullness of divine election and the universality of God's plan, later seen in the Church's call to all nations.

verses.text: therefore, I am about to expose the flank of Moab, beginning with its frontier cities—the glory of the land, Beth-jeshimoth, Baal-meon, and Kiriathaim—given to the people of the east, along with all the rest of Moab.
verses.comment: The mention of specific locations underlines the thoroughness of judgment. The loss of territorial glory invites reflection on spiritual riches versus earthly possessions (Matt. 6:19–20).

verses.text: I will hand it over with the sons of Ammon to the people of the east, so that the sons of Ammon will no longer be remembered among the nations.
verses.comment: Being forgotten among nations shows the gravity of separation from God's covenant, underscoring the biblical theme of remembrance and legacy, which finds fulfillment in the new community established by Christ.

verses.text: I will execute judgments on Moab, and they will know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Once more, God's judgments are ultimately revelatory. The repetition echoes the motif that recognition of the Lord is the true end—pointing ahead to Trinitarian revelation in the New Testament.

verses.text: This is what the Lord GOD says: Because Edom acted in revenge against the house of Judah and is greatly guilty for avenging itself upon them,
verses.comment: Edom's vengeance ties into the larger biblical theme of resisting retaliation, which Christ explicitly fulfills through His teaching on forgiveness (Matt. 5:39–40).

verses.text: therefore thus says the Lord GOD: I will stretch out My hand against Edom and cut off both man and beast from it. I will make it desolate; from Teman to Dedan they shall fall by the sword.
verses.comment: The destruction of Edom from Teman to Dedan—well-known Edomite cities—signifies God's comprehensive justice, prefiguring the final victory of God over all opposition (Rev. 19:15).

verses.text: I will lay My vengeance upon Edom by the hand of My people Israel. They shall act in Edom according to My anger and My fury. Then they shall know My vengeance, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: God uses His people as instruments of justice—a theme deepened in spiritual warfare and fulfilled in the Church's mission to bring the world under divine mercy and authority.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord GOD: Because the Philistines acted in vengeance and took revenge with malice of soul, intending destruction with lasting hostility,
verses.comment: The Philistines' enduring hostility toward Israel is part of the persistent biblical tension between the faithful and the corrupt, which finds resolution in the establishment of God's promised reign.

verses.text: therefore thus says the Lord GOD: I will stretch out My hand against the Philistines, and I will cut off the Cherethites and destroy those remaining on the coast.
verses.comment: The Cherethites, linked to the Philistines, symbolize persistent opposition to God’s ways. The motif of judgment over coastal peoples also foreshadows later calls to the ends of the earth (Acts 1:8).

verses.text: I will execute great vengeance upon them with furious rebukes. When I inflict My vengeance on them, they shall know that I am the LORD."
verses.comment: Final emphasis on judgment for the sake of knowledge of God. This knowledge ultimately finds its completion in revelation of Christ as Lord and Judge (Matt. 25:31–32).
